metadata.title: Supporting information Post-translational modification directs nuclear and hyphal tip localization of C. albicans mRNA-binding protein Slr1

body_text.text: To test whether Slr1 binds to polyadenylated mRNA, a UV crosslinking assay developed to detect mRNA-binding proteins in S. cerevisiae (Marfatia et al., 2003) was adapted for C. albicans. Slr1-TAP-expressing cells (SLR1-TAP/slr1∆; AMC94) were grown in 1 L YPD to OD 600 =1. Cells were collected, washed in PBS and irradiated in a petri dish on ice with UV light in a Stratalinker 2400 with four 2.5 min pulses. A control sample was incubated on ice without irradiation for the same time. Cells were collected, washed with PBS and divided into 6 screw-cap microfuge tubes and lysed with 0.5 mL glass beads in 50 µl lysis buffer (ULB: 20 mM Tris pH7.5, 50 mM LiCl, 1% SDS, 1 mM EDTA, 1% ß-mercaptoethanol, 1 mg mL -1 heparin (Sigma), 20 mM ribonucleoside vanadyl complexes (New England Biolabs)) in a Fastprep disruptor at level 6.5 for one 30s cycle and one 21s cycle. Following addition of 0.55-0.58 mL ice-cold lysis buffer, lysates were mixed and clarified by two 10-minute centrifugations at 16,000xg and 4°C.

To purify polyadenylated RNAs, lysates were adjusted to 0.5 M LiCl, 5 µl RNase inhibitor (Promega) were added and lysates were transfered to tubes with 200 mg oligo (dT) cellulose resin that had been pre-swollen for 1 h in elution buffer (10 mM Tris pH7.4, 1 mM EDTA, 0.05% SDS). Oligo dT-binding buffer (10 mM Tris pH 7.4, 1 mM EDTA, 0.5% SDS, 0.5 M LiCl) was added to a 10 mL final volume and the lysate and resin incubated with rocking for 2 h at 4°C. Cellulose was washed twice with 5 mL oligo dT binding buffer, resuspended in 4 mL binding buffer, collected in a poly-prep column (Biorad) and oligo (dT)-bound complexes eluted with 3 mL elution buffer.

To prepare for a second round of purification, eluates were heated to 65°C for 10 min, cooled immediately on ice for 10 min, and adjusted to 0.5 M LiCl. Cellulose resin was washed with 10 mL binding buffer. Eluates were then added to the washed resins, which were then washed with 10 mL binding buffer prior to elution with 3 mL elution buffer.

To collect RNA-protein complexes, eluates were first concentrated by three extractions with 2 volumes of 2-butanol until the aqueous phase was less than 0.5 mL. The concentrated eluates were adjusted to 0.2M LiCl and two volumes of 100% ethanol were added. RNA-protein complexes were precipitated by overnight incubation at -80°C and centrifugation. Pellets were washed with 70% ice-cold ethanol and resuspended in 30 µl RSB (10 mM Tris-HCl pH 7.4, 100 mM NaCl, 2.5 mM MgCl 2 , 1 mM CaCl 2 ) with protease inhibitors. Relative RNA concentrations were determined by absorbance at 260 nm with a Nanodrop ND-1000 spectrophotometer. RNAs were digested by incubation with 0.5 µl RNase A (10 mg mL -1 ) and 1 µl micrococcal nuclease (New England Biolabs) at 30°C for 40 min. Following addition of loading buffer, samples were resolved by SDS-10% PAGE and then presence of Slr1-TAP in oligo d(T)-bound material was analyzed by immunoblotting with an anti-Protein A (PrA) antibody (Rockland; 1:10,000 dilution).

slr1∆::hisG/SLR1 strain Heterozygous slr1∆::hisG/SLR1 strains were obtained by transforming BWP17 and AMC36 (hmt1∆/∆) with SacI-KpnI-cut pAM489 (Ariyachet et al., 2013) to yield AMC91 and AMC92, respectively. These strains allowed the expression of tagged Slr1 proteins as the sole copy of Slr1 in the presence or absence of arginine methylation, as described below.

To obtain a strain expressing Slr1-GFP, the 3' end of SLR1 was tagged with GFP by amplification of a GFP-HIS1 cassette from pMG1646 (Gerami-Nejad et al., 2001) with primer pair AM318 and AM319 and transformation into BWP17 (Wilson et al., 1999) . Slr1-GFP expression by resulting strain AMC84 was verified by anti-GFP immunoblotting and fluorescence microscopy.

To create a plasmid from which the GFP-HIS1 cassette with SLR1 flanking regions (609 and 541 nucleotides before and after the stop codon) could be excised, this region was amplified from AMC84 genomic DNA with two primer pairs: AM344/345 and AM346/347. PCR products from AM344/345 amplification were digested with SacI and XbaI and inserted into SacI/XbaI-cut pRS316, resulting in pAM473. PCR fragments from AM346/347 amplification were digested with XbaI and KpnI and inserted into XbaI/KpnI-cut pAM473, yielding pAM474. Digestion of pAM474 with SacI and KpnI released the fragment for integration of the GFP-HIS1 cassette at the 3'end of SLR1. The integrity of the SLR1 flanking regions in pAM474 was confirmed by sequencing at Geneway Research (Hayward, CA).

To create a cassette for integration of GFP at the 3' end of SLR1 with a URA3 marker gene, the HIS1 sequence was deleted from pAM474 by digestion with EcoRI and re-circularization, resulting in pAM475. To insert the URA3 marker into pAM475, pDS10 was digested with XbaI to release URA3, which was incorporated into XbaI-digested pAM475, yielding pAM476.

To generate the slr1-6SA-GFP-URA3 cassette encoding six serine-to-alanine mutations, the 3'SLR1 flanking region was released from pAM476 by SacI and XhoI digest and inserted into a SacI/XhoI-cut Amp r -containing fragment of pDS10 (Park et al., 2005) , resulting in pAM477. The S-to-A mutations at codon positions 257 and 259 were introduced into pAM477 by QuikChange II XL Site-Directed Mutagenesis (Stratagene) using oligonucleotides AM368 and AM369, yielding pAM479. S-to-A mutations at codon positions 244, 246, 248 and 250 were next introduced into pAM479 by the same approach, using primers AM377 and AM378, yielding pAM483. To obtain the full-length slr1-6SA-GFP-URA3 cassette, XhoI/KpnI-cut fragment of pAM476 was inserted into XhoI/KpnI-digested pAM483, resulting in pAM484. This plasmid contains a GFP tagging cassette with six S-to-A mutations in SLR1.

To create the SLR1-GFP-URA3 cassette with partial deletion of the R-rich domain, an XhoI/KpnI-cut fragment of pAM476 was inserted into XhoI/KpnI-digested pAM477, resulting in pAM481. A synonomous mutation at codon 193 (TACàTAT) was introduced into pAM481 to generate additional NruI and EcoRV restriction sites, yielding pAM496. Two partial deletions (∆D123-R194 and ∆Y151-G192) of the R-rich domain were generated by digesting pAM496 with NruI and EcoRV, respectively. NruI-cut pAM496 was re-circularized to obtain pAM482, whereas 6.3-kb and 1.2-kb fragments from EcoRV digest were ligated, yielding pAM485.

Digestion of wildtype and mutant SLR1-GFP URA3 cassette plasmids with SacI and KpnI, followed by transformation into C. albicans using a lithium acetate-based transformation protocol (Wilson et al., 1999) allowed integration at the native SLR1 locus, as summarized in Table S1 . Proper integration was tested by PCR and expression tested by anti-GFP immunoblotting.

To allow the addition of a tandem-affinity-purification (TAP) tag to Slr1 at the C-terminus, the 3' end of SLR1 (654 bp before the stop codon) was amplified from BWP17 genomic DNA using AM379 and AM380. PCR fragments were digested with NsiI and XmaI and inserted into NsiI/XmaI-cut pJR75 (Blackwell & Brown, 2009) , resulting in pAM491. NruI-cut pAM491 was transformed into AMC91, yielding AMC94. Proper integration of the TAP-tag was verified by PCR, and expression of the full-length Slr1-TAP was confirmed by anti-PrA immunoblotting.

To create the GFP-tagging cassette with a HIS1 marker, HIS1 was released from pGEMHIS1 (Wilson et al., 1999) by SacII and XbaI digest and inserted into SacII/XbaI-cut pJR75, yielding pAM492. To replace TAP with a GFP tag, GFP was amplified from AMC84 genomic DNA using AM402 and AM403. PCR products were digested with NsiI and NheI and inserted into NsiI/NheIcut pAM492, yielding pAM493. The 3' ends of ORF19.387 and ORF19.763 (555 and 501 nucleotides before the stop codon) were amplified from BWP17 genomic DNA with two primer pairs: AM404/405 and AM406/407. PCR products from AM404/405 and AM406/407 amplification were digested with HindIII and NsiI and inserted into HindIII/NsiI-cut pAM493, resulting in pAM494 and pAM495, respectively. Digestion of these plasmids with ClaI and transformation into AMC94 and AMC91 allowed expression of Orf19.387-GFP and Orf19.763-GFP in strains with (AMC108, AMC109) and without (AMC106, AMC107) Slr1-TAP. Expression of the fusion proteins was confirmed by GFP microscopy and anti-GFP immunoblotting.

To determine whether the cytoplasmic fluorescence in cells expressing wildtype Slr1-GFP could be due to autofluorescence, log-phase cells expressing either Slr1-GFP or no GFP were grown to log phase in synthetic minimal medium lacking uridine at 30°C. Cells were washed with PBS and subsequently incubated with 10 µg mL -1 DAPI (4',6-diamidono-2-phenylindole; Molecular Probes) in PBS for 4 min. at 30°C. Cells were washed PBS, placed on agarose-coated slides and visualized by brightfield and widefield epifluorescence microscopy (Olympus BX51: 100x objective, GFP and DAPI filters). Images were captured with an EvolutionVF color digital camera (noncooled, 12-bit; MediaCybernetics) and QCapture Pro 5.0 software. For each filter, exposure times for the two strains were identical.
body_text.section: Fluorescence image analysis: Mean cytoplasmic GFP fluorescence intensity calculation

body_text.text: To quantify mean cytoplasmic GFP fluorescence intensity, first the brightness/contrast levels of all DAPI images were first adjusted equivalently in Adobe Photoshop CS5 to lower background cytoplasmic DAPI fluorescence. GFP, DAPI and brightfield images were then stacked in ImageJ v1.49 (Schneider et al., 2012) and cells with in-focus nuclei were identified. For each cell, the whole cell and the nucleus were selected on DIC and DAPI images, respectively, and area (A) and average pixel intensity (API) measured for each selection on the GFP image. Selection was performed in triplicate for each cell using a Wacom Cintiq 13HD touch tablet; the mean of the three area and API measurements was used for subsequent calculations. For each image, the API of background regions lacking cells was subtracted from the whole-cell and nuclear API measurements. The total nuclear and whole cell pixel intensities (TPI N and TPI WC ) were calculated by multiplying the average area (A) by the background-adjusted API. Mean cytoplasmic GFP fluorescence intensity was calculated as follows: (TPI WC -TPI N )/(A WC -A N ). Figure S1 : ClustalW sequence alignment of fungal Slr1/Srp1 family RRM domains Fungal RRM domains similar to C. albicans Slr1 (Calb) were identified by BLAST and aligned with clustalW. Residues in boldface within the boxed regions are identical to a conserved motif found in metazoan SR proteins (Birney et al., 1993) . Identical (*), strongly conserved (:) and weakly conserved (.) residues are indicated. CaSlr1-family RRMs are shown for the following fungi: Debaromyces hansenii (Dhan), Malassezia globosa (Mglo), Ustilago maydis (Umay), Aspergillus nidulans (Anid), Neurospora crassa (Ncra), Schizosaccharomyces pombe (Spom), Yarrowia lipolytica (Ylip), Lachancea kluyveri (Lklu), Lachancea thermotolerans (Lthe), Ashbya gossypii (Agos) and Kluyveromyces lactis (Klac).
body_text.section: Fluorescence image analysis: Mean cytoplasmic GFP fluorescence intensity calculation

body_text.text: C. albicans cells expressing wildtype Slr1-GFP (WT), slr1-GFP lacking amino acids 151-192 (∆151-192) or slr1-GFP lacking amino acids 123-194 (∆123-194) were grown overnight in synthetic medium lacking uridine. Cells were collected, washed in water and lysed in RIPA buffer containing protease inhibitors, and 40 µg total protein resolved by SDS-10%PAGE. Slr1-GFP proteins were detected by anti-GFP immunoblot. Note the similar levels of expression among the three independently isolated strains for each protein (indicated with a bracket; asterisks indicate strains AMC96-98, which are shown in Fig. 3) and among the three different Slr1-GFP proteins. In addition, no additional faster migrating proteins were detected for the deletion mutant proteins, indicating that cytoplasmic fluorescence of the mutant proteins is not due to protein degradation. Cells expressing Slr1-GFP (AMC96) or no GFP (AMC81) were grown to mid-log phase in synthetic medium, stained with DAPI and imaged by epifluorescence microscopy. GFP, DAPI and brightfield images were stacked in ImageJ (Schneider et al., 2012) , and the mean GFP fluorescence intensity and area of each cell (defined by DIC) and nucleus (defined by DAPI) were measured, adjusted for extracellular background fluorescence and used to calculate mean cytoplasmic fluorescence. Cytoplasmic fluorescence in cells expressing Slr1-GFP was significantly higher than in cells lacking GFP (*p<0.0001, student's t-test; n=19-20 cells per strain). Negative values for mean cytoplasmic fluorescence in cells lacking GFP indicate lower intracellular than extracellular background fluorescence.
body_text.section: Figure S2: Deletions in the RG domain do not affect Slr1-GFP expression levels

body_text.text: Cells expressing slr1-6SA-GFP (slr1-6SA-GFP/slr1∆)(A) or Spitzenkörper protein Mlc1-YFP (MLC1-YFP/MLC1) (B) were induced to form hyphae for 3 h in RPMI at 37°C prior to staining with FM4-64 for 4 min. After washing in warm PBS, cells were rapidly imaged at room temperature by epifluorescence microscopy on agarose-coated slides. GFP and FM4-64 (Texas Red filter) with without DIC images were overlaid in Adobe Photoshop 5.0, with brightness and contrast levels adjusted to facilitate visualization of hyphal foci (panel a). Original GFP, FM4-64 and DIC images were also stacked in ImageJ v.1.49 (Schneider et al., 2012) . For each hypha numbered in panel a, the center of the GFP/YFP and FM4-64 tip focus was identified as the pixel with highest fluorescence intensity, and then the fluorescence intensity at each pixel along a line intersecting the GFP/YFP and FM4-64 center points was measured (panels b-f). Note the overlap of the slr1-6SA-GFP and Mlc1-YFP signals with the FM4-64 signal in each of the five hyphae.
body_text.section: Figure S4: Partial co-localization of hyphal tip foci with the Spitzenkörper: Line scans
